title: Firm restructuring Guangdong Zhenrong makes claim from oil trader Mercuria
text:
By Shu Zhang and Julia Payne

SINGAPORE/LONDON, Oct 24 (Reuters) - Global energy trader Mercuria said the firm restructuring China's bankrupt trading firm Guangdong Zhenrong is threatening it with legal action for allegedly failing to fulfill oil contracts.

Mercuria said on Thursday its Singapore arm had "received a letter from Hong Kong solicitors purporting to act for the bankruptcy administrator of Guangdong Zhenrong Energy Company".

Chinese news outlet Caixin reported earlier on Thursday that state-backed Guangdong Zhenrong was claiming 40 billion yuan ($5.66 billion) from Mercuria.

Guangdong Zhenrong could not immediately be reached for comment. Its bankruptcy administrator's lawyefine r declined to comment.

Mercuria said it had "fully performed" its contractual obligations with the Chinese firm adding that the "allegations relate to contracts entered into by the parties some 5-6 years ago and have never been raised before now."

Chinese commodity trader Guangdong Zhenrong Energy Co is partly owned by Zhuhai Zhenrong Corp which has been sanctioned by the U.S. government for dealings in Iranian oil. ($1 = 7.0723 Chinese yuan renminbi) (Reporting By Shu Zhang in Singapore and Julia Payne in London, Editing by Alexandra Hudson)
